title: 111_hr1845
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Development Centers Modernization Act of 2009". It includes operational changes for Small Business Development Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to require accreditation for institutions of higher education. Program negotiations now require mutual agreement. Contract negotiations are also subject to changes. The Small Business Act is amended to require accreditation for institutions of higher education and program negotiations now require mutual agreement. Contract negotiations and SBDC hiring procedures are also updated. The Small Business Act is amended to limit expenses to $500,000 and allow non-matching portability grants in case of a disaster. Additionally, there is a new limitation on distribution to Small Business Development Centers. The Small Business Act is amended to limit expenses to $500,000 and allow non-matching portability grants in case of a disaster. The Administration shall not distribute funds to a Small Business Development Center if the State is served by more than one center, with exceptions for unavailability and grandfather clause. The Small Business Act is amended to define Small Business Development Centers and Women's Business Centers. Women's Business Centers operating under section 29 are no longer included in the definition. The Small Business Act is amended to define Small Business Development Centers and Women's Business Centers. Women's Business Centers operating under section 29 are no longer included in the definition. Access to credit and capital is emphasized. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to assist in securing capital and repairing credit. This program includes developing specialized programs, providing informational seminars, and offering one-on-one counseling. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to assist in securing capital and repairing credit. The program includes one-on-one counseling with borrowers to improve financial presentations and facilitate access to financing sources. The Administration may award up to $300,000 in grant funds and is authorized to appropriate up to $2,500,000 for this purpose. The Small Business Act authorizes up to $2,500,000 for a grant program to help small business development centers secure capital and improve credit from 2010 to 2011. SEC. 4. PROCUREMENT TRAINING AND ASSISTANCE. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to help them identify suitable contracts and prepare for subcontracting and prime contracting opportunities. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to provide training, business advisement, technical assistance on federal procurement, and compliance with regulations. The Administration may award up to $300,000 in grant funds and make grants or enter into cooperative agreements for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations up to $2,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 to carry out the grant program for small business development centers. SEC. 5. GREEN ENTREPRENEURS TRAINING PROGRAM. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Green Entrepreneurs Training Program grant for small business development centers to provide education in energy efficiency, green technology, and clean technology. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Green Entrepreneurs Training Program grant for small business development centers. The grant aims to coordinate classes with local community colleges and trade associations, provide technical counseling for starting or adapting businesses in energy efficiency, green technology, or clean technology fields, and assist low-income or dislocated workers in starting businesses in these fields. The Administration may award up to $300,000 in grant funds to an entity. The Administration may award more than $300,000 in grant funds under this subsection, with authorized appropriations not exceeding $2,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. SEC. 6. MAIN STREET STABILIZATION. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to provide assistance and resources to struggling small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to provide growth tools, resources, expert consulting, and education to struggling small businesses. Additional resources will be deployed to help specific industry sectors with similar needs and financing options will be listed. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a grant program for small business development centers to provide growth tools, resources, expert consulting, and education to struggling small businesses. The program aims to list financing options for small business capital access and assist dislocated workers in starting new businesses. Grant funds are limited to $250,000 per entity, with an authorization of up to $2,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. SEC. 7 prohibits the use of program income as matching funds. SEC. 8 authorizes appropriations for Small Business Development Centers. SEC. 9 establishes the Small Manufacturers Transition Assistance Program. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a Small Manufacturers Transition Assistance Program, providing grants to small business development centers for technical assistance to small manufacturers in changing or reorganizing operations. The Small Manufacturers Transition Assistance Program aims to support small manufacturers by providing technical assistance, marketing capabilities, facilitating relationships, and conducting outreach activities. Small manufacturers are defined as small businesses in specific industries, and there is a limit on award size for the program. The Small Manufacturers Transition Assistance Program limits grant awards to $250,000 per entity. The Administration is authorized to allocate up to $2,500,000 for this program in fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The Small Manufacturers Transition Assistance Program limits grant awards to $250,000 per entity, with the Administration authorized to allocate up to $2,500,000 for this program in fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
